NEXT COTILLON IS
POSTPONED BY BOARD
The Cotillon Board announced today that the Third
Cotillon scheduled, for April
13th, had been indefinitely
postptitied due to the lack of
support given the two previous
Cotillons of the present college year.
A regular Saturday night
dance in the C. E. Hall has
been arranged to take the place
of the Cotillon. The remain7
der .of the dances as advertised
by the Cotillon Board are to
be held as scheduled.

Conquering the Cascades
falls every month in the
year where the Great Northern
crosses the Cascades. Steep, tortuous
grades increase the difficulty of the
railroading problem. Nature has stubbornly resisted man's effort to conquer'•
the range.
In January, 1929, the new Cascade
tunnel was opened. Man, with electricity as an ally, had conquered the Cascades.
The eight-mile bore was
driven in three years— a

C NOW

record impossible without electric
power. And electrification has been
extended to the entire 75-mile route
through the mountains.
The conquests of electricity on the
land and on the sea, in the air, and
underground, are making Rracticable
the impossibilities of yesterday._ As
our vision encompasses wider- horizons, electricity appears as
a vital contribution to future
industrial progress and human
welfare.

Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
Replying to your circular letter of
June 29, be informed that/bur sample
packages were received. With them
I received the pamphItt describing
your product, which I was able to
enjoy reading because there was not
in the circular matter the usual distasteful sales talk which makes the
recipient of a sample package feel
obligated or uncomfortable.
I believe your practice of giving
your prospect a sample and then
letting him make up his own mind
will gain you many more customers
than will the usual modern sales practice of pushing the product down the
prospect's throat. As a matter of fact,
since receiving your sample and your
advertising matter I smoked up the
sample package and have since pur'chased a number of cans from neighborhood dealers, all of whom carry
this tobacco in a city of this size.
I have found Edgeworth to be a
,satisfactory blend at a very reasonable price, and although my past acquaintance is brief, I look forward toe
long membership in the Edgeworth
Club.
Yours very truly,
Jeff Corydon

label was numbered. This was
judged to be the most Sporting way
of testing the merits of the four
leading brands. Some 208 Yale
students were asked to smoke the
four disguised brands without
knowing their identity.

broken up over the degree to which
a scarf will be permitted to "choke."
"California, here I stay!" •
As for the University of Southern California, their lot is hard also!
Instead of being bothered with such
inconveniences as quizzes they have
merely to take "screen tests." These
tests are given in a course offered
at the university in motion-picture
acting and photography. The students are trained under the supervision of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios at Culver City.
Here at last is a way to go to
college and become a millionaire!

be found in the "floating university"

members of the student and faculty
bodies at the University of Michigan who have attended one or more
of the courses. )

A regular Saturday night

been arranged to take the place
of the Cotillon. The remain7
der .of the dances as advertised
by the Cotillon Board are to
be held as scheduled.

Conquering the Cascades
falls every month in the
year where the Great Northern
crosses the Cascades. Steep, tortuous
grades increase the difficulty of the
railroading problem. Nature has stubbornly resisted man's effort to conquer'•
the range.
In January, 1929, the new Cascade
tunnel was opened. Man, with electricity as an ally, had conquered the Cascades.
The eight-mile bore was
driven in three years— a

C NOW

record impossible without electric
power. And electrification has been
extended to the entire 75-mile route
through the mountains.
The conquests of electricity on the
land and on the sea, in the air, and
underground, are making Rracticable
the impossibilities of yesterday._ As
our vision encompasses wider- horizons, electricity appears as
a vital contribution to future
industrial progress and human
welfare.

Richmond, Va.
Gentlemen:
Replying to your circular letter of
June 29, be informed that/bur sample
packages were received. With them
I received the pamphItt describing
your product, which I was able to
enjoy reading because there was not
in the circular matter the usual distasteful sales talk which makes the
recipient of a sample package feel
obligated or uncomfortable.
I believe your practice of giving
your prospect a sample and then
letting him make up his own mind
will gain you many more customers
than will the usual modern sales practice of pushing the product down the
prospect's throat. As a matter of fact,
since receiving your sample and your
advertising matter I smoked up the
sample package and have since pur'chased a number of cans from neighborhood dealers, all of whom carry
this tobacco in a city of this size.
I have found Edgeworth to be a
,satisfactory blend at a very reasonable price, and although my past acquaintance is brief, I look forward toe
long membership in the Edgeworth
Club.
Yours very truly,
Jeff Corydon

The Jay attack never let up its
hard fighting. Mallonee, the only
Olympic who played the whole
game was showing signs of wear
Carrol Berndt, who had only ten
minutes' rest, was the only one
of the Olympic defenders who
seemed to hold up.
Campbell Tallier

The half was two-thirds gone
when Addison Campbell .made,
what even oldtimers admitted,
was one of the sthoothe,g plays
to tally the varsity's _last goal,
they had ever seen. Standing on
the edge of a mass play in front
of goal, Campbell caught what
was more nearly a fumble than a
pass and sent the ball throtigh
the crowd, past Finn, into thf
Olympic net.
After Campbell's goal, even
Benny. Boynton himself agreed to
give himself a rest and give his
job to flying Frank Dotterweich.
Even Pop Finn, who has grown
slightly corpulent since last
spring, quitted his net to take
Lefty Leibensperger's old job on
the crease, while George Miller
assumed the job of net guardian.
'rhiS combination worked fine
while the ball was down at the
other end of the field, although
Miller did stop one short just .as
the whistle blew.

FIRST IN TESTS AT YALE
In the recent cigarette test made at
the University, OLD GOLDS were
chosen by the students as the best.
The cigarettes were masked by
black labels so that the names of
the brands were concealed. Each
label was numbered. This was
judged to be the most Sporting way
of testing the merits of the four
leading brands. Some 208 Yale
students were asked to smoke the
four disguised brands without
knowing their identity.

new spring styles among the men
and women students at the University of California, an annual spring
fashion number of the. daily newspaper at that institution appeared

consisted of four pages of style,
prevalent at the university, and ample suggestion to any student desirous of becoming outstandingly well

be the thing for discussion in smart
circles. Debates will be centered
around the angle at which suspenders will be worn, and friendships
broken up over the degree to which
a scarf will be permitted to "choke."
"California, here I stay!" •
As for the University of Southern California, their lot is hard also!
Instead of being bothered with such
inconveniences as quizzes they have
merely to take "screen tests." These
tests are given in a course offered
at the university in motion-picture
acting and photography. The students are trained under the supervision of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios at Culver City.
Here at last is a way to go to
college and become a millionaire!

the collegiate world of today cah
be found in the "floating university"
towns, according to reports from
members of the student and faculty
bodies at the University of Michigan who have attended one or more
of the courses. )
